title: Before 1 May 2021, will it be officially announced that the Tokyo 2020 Summer Olympics and/or Paralympics will be canceled?
preds: There is currently COVID wave going on in multiple countries and chances of olympics happening is low. However, today is 4/30 so whether we will get announcement by tomorrow is low
I just signed in. We are the 30th of April . The olympics are still planned and only 50 mn before the 1sr of may

The torch is currently in Okinawa: https://olympics.com/tokyo-2020/en/torch/route/okinawa/
I just don't think they're actually gonna cancel it (if they are gonna cancel it) until late June, once the torch is starting to get closer to Tokyo.

As a last resort, the Games could be held without local spectators behind closed doors.
https://www.euronews.com/2021/04/30/tokyo-olympics-organiser-says-biggest-event-in-sporting-calendar-could-be-held-without-spe
could still happen today - but as it is 10 pm in Japan now... very unlikely..
There's only one day before May 1st.
absolutely no evidence they are going to cancel the games by EOD; in fact they are talking about holding them without an audience.

There's only 20 hours left to this (I just signed up). The organisers recently (this week) started talking about there plans to ensure they go ahead. Smaller sporting events have been going ahead for a while now (football in the UK) with the compromise that fans aren't there. The current crisis point for covid is in india, and that has been bad since this week when the new plans were announced/ PRed. I don't think anything could happen in the next 20 hours that would cause the immediate cancelling of the games before 1st May
Updating the day before it closes.   No sign of it being cancelled today
Only 5 previous Olympic games have been canceled and they all were associated with war. There is only one day left in the window of cancellation for any yes answer to be correct.

There is a surge of COVID cases in Japan, making the likelihood of Olympic cancellation non-zero. The Paralympics are after the Olympics and will likely occur while a Olympics-triggered surge of COVID rises. If the Olympics is cancelled then the Paralympics will be as well. I think it is very likely that neither will be cancelled though.
With the end coming near, and the absence of such an announcement with the COVID cases in Japan coming down from a peak, I am virtually certain no such announcement will be made before May 1, 2021.
Changing forecast based on updated information
Attendance may be curtailed, a bubble may be forced but the investment has been made and the world is clamoring to have the old normal move to the next normal.
Double variant on the rise, inadequate vaccination in majority of participating countries

The last round of swimming qualifications for the olympics will start on the 1st of May. Australia has already withdrawn its team (powerhouse in swimming). But the news so far from the head of the Tokyo Olympics has been that a cancellation is not in plans. Given how the number of Covid cases have not changed much since the last announcement, furthermore, this new emergency state will last until the 11th of May. So I don't believe any big decision will be taken until the results of this new lockdown.

Not quite ready to go to 100% "No," but adjusting forecast in that direction.  Considering the COVID problems that Japan has been facing that past couple of weeks, there could still be a surprise announcement in the next 48 hours.

The organizers will try to delay the decision for another week or two, so I think a firm decision will only come in June. The Olympics might be delayed. The one single  event in Barcelona with people attending a live event is not enough to give any certainty that such a big event could be safely controlled. And the new evolutions in India will raise the concerns of a new virus variant.
May 1 is simply too close - even given COVID I don’t see anything materially changing the situation between now and three days from now.

Given we are in a pandemic, India rates increasing, vaccines have not been equitably distributed the olylmpics should be postponed.  But given the financial implications, and the fact that many other sports are resuming when effective testing and policy regarding vaccines are available
Most major sporting events going ahead despite COVID-19 severity e.g. IPL cricket
May 1st is too early; it will happen later

Overall, the likelihood that the Olympics will be cancelled or at least postponed again is increasing, but the window on this question is closing soon.  Right now, it probably about 60/40 that a major announcement regarding the Olympics is made this week, but that does not mean that the announcement is cancellation.  As a result of the windowing closing on the question and that I believe that it is more likely that any announcement will more likely be a postponement rather than a cancellation, I am slightly increase my probability of "No."
Not impossible but with only three days left very very unlikely

The timeline make it rather unlikely, but the surging number of cases (https://www.google.com/search?q=Japan%20covid%20number%20of%20cases&oq=Japan%20covid%20number%20of%20cases&sourceid=chrome&from=coli) and this article (https://www.foxsports.com.au/olympics/tokyo-olympics-2021-cancelled-coronavirus-covid19-toshiro-nikai-crowds/news-story/495941de5b1124293728d96a35ef8ec1) made me thinking that it wasn't that unlikely.
Very unlikely with so few days left.

Many of the towns around Tokyo that were scheduled to host athletes are balking. Japan has a worrying second wave less than 100 days before the games begin. It looks more like a 50-50 thing at this point.
We are almost at May 1 and still the 'official' position is - we can hold the Games!

Updating my forecast daily this week to creep closer to 100% No.  However, the reports out of Japan (COVID surge, emergency near-lockdowns, strong public opinion opposition, etc.) should continued to monitored, but it remains highly unlikely the Olympics will be cancelled by Saturday.
Seems overwhelmingly likely now. Sense checked google trends- don't see any obvious indication of cancellation.
only a few days left, possibility of running the olympics without fans included in the non-cancel choice.

Starting with crowd forecast (average of last 7 days) puts it at around 5% for yes for both. Recent news seems to suggest that despite the recent news in Japan, a reversal at this point (5 days out) seems very unlikely.
Even though Japan is now in a third state of emergency, the Tokyo Olympic committee just announced that it would require more Covid testing and not the 14 day quarantine

The president of the Olympic organizing committee has stated that a cancelation is not being considered. https://www.japantimes.co.jp/news/2021/04/24/national/tokyo-olympics-cancellation-coronavirus/ Given this news, a cancelation prior to May 1st does not seem likely.

Holding forecast steady for today, but events over the weekend increases the overall likelihood that Olympics could be postponed, but the likelihood such an announcement coming before Saturday continues to decrease.  The recent surge in Japan and the declaration of emergency with near lockdown conditions in four regions of the county is placing a lot of pressure on the government and the IOC to postpone.  A majority of Japanese oppose holding the Olympics this year by an overwhelming margin.  The solid and near definitive declaration of the Japanese government that the Olympics will be held this year is surprising, because it is a relatively new government or at least a relatively new prime minister, which could face an electoral backlash for their deafness of public opinion on the issue.  Will continue to monitor this question closely throughout the week, but expect the answer to reach near 100% "no" by the end of the week.
En ce moment, le Japon n'est pas un pays assez sécuritaire pour tenir les Jeux Olympiques. Il reste à déterminer si l'annulation complète aura lieu avant le 1er mai.
State of emergency in main cities of Tokyo, Osaka and two others are in place until 11 May. It would make sense to wait until then before Japan decides on whether to cancel the Olympics.

While Japan's vaccine rollout has not been stellar to say the least, with only 6 days left until May 1st, it seems unlikely for a sudden cancellation to happen. I am taking into account the fact that while it is very possible for the cancellation to happen at all, 6 days is a short period of time, even when Japan's Economic Minister, Yasutoshi Nishimura, says it's not off the table. Additionally, the economic incentives for both games to go on are not substantial like past years, since they are not allowing foreign fans into the games. Cancelling both would be the best economic outcome for them, despite their preparation.

Even if the obstacles to holding the Olympics are high, the pre-2020 investments, the face-saving motivations for Japan are significant. Other sports venues are starting to implement alternate measures to have at least limited in-person fans in-spite of the pandemic, and the committees involved are sure to be calculating the impact of vaccines. Most of all, officials are likely to wait as late as possible to make such an announcement.
"Before 1 May 2021" not likely, even if they were to cancel
Japan is determined to host the Olympics, and with just a week left before May 1, extremely unlikely they will be canceled. Even more unlikely that only Olympics are canceled and not Paralympics.

NOT Losing face is a huge motivator in Japanese culture - they are so far along at this point there must be plans to go forward.  Many big sports leagues have continued.  There have been whispers of it being postponed but they are quickly denied.

Firstly, it seems very unlikely that the cancellation decisions can diverge for both events, since the decision makers are IOC & the Japanese Govt . Even if there could be good reasons why only one of the events should be cancelled, explaining that decision would be a PR nightmare. That should take options 1 & 2 off the table. As per option 3, Japan has international support to go ahead with the games. Only an extreme scenario could change that : such as a sharp rise in Covid cases or deaths or a one-off event. Given that only a week is left, ~ 2%

BUT (and it is a big but) I also get the sense, that public opinion in Japan is getting less favorable of the olympics with rising case numbers and death toll, and more severe strains of COVID spreading. I actually think the overall propability of cancelation of the Olympics is rising, but don't think it will happen before 1 May, that is why I increase the chance of No.

Based on some additional research and speaking with a friend that was in the Rio Paralympics, I do not believe that the Paralympics can be cancelled with out cancelling the Olympics.  While just cancelling the Paralympics might make some sense in order to prevent spread of COVID, there would be significant global backless from the disable communities.  And while it is becoming increasingly clear that the IOC and government of Japan are determined to hold the Tokyo Olympics, I still believe that it is not a certainty based on recent polling that suggests 60% to 70% of Japanese do not want to hold the Olympics this year and spike in COVID cases the country is currently experiencing.  Throughout next week, I expect that my estimate on not cancelling either will steadily increase to near 100%.

There is no reason to cancel only one of the two games. Therefore, the choice really is between both being canceled or neither being canceled. At present it appears that there is no indication that a cancelation is imminent. There are only 10 days until the deadline, which is a short period for sudden change in direction.

I forecast 90% because a decision to cancel the games does not seem likely prior to the IOC visit and after the US obtained additional vaccines to assist Japan in containing its spread of the virus.  https://www.theguardian.com/world/2021/apr/18/tokyo-2021-olympic-chief-to-visit-japan-to-approve-safety-amid-covid-cases-surge

It still seems highly unlikely but with these developments and cases on the rise with emergency declarations coming there is more of a chance.

Japan is currently under the administration of the Liberal Democratic Party, a very conservative party present within Japan's political system. Japan has always had very stringent immigration controls, of which were only further tightened during the COVID-19 pandemic. Consequently, Japan has done fairly well during the pandemic in terms of infections and especially infection deaths per capita. Even so, there is mounting political pressure on Japan's politicians to ease restrictions, and, given Japan's rivalry with, China, who enjoyed hosting the Olympics in 2008 (in which China beat out Japan in terms of medals earned), the Japanese government is very unlikely to cancel the Olympics.

The IOC has demonstrated flexibility in the past, no so much in the recent past with the exception of last year's postponement, to make adjustments based on global events, including pushing back the location of an Olympics by four years, but still holding the events. Based on Olympic athletes concerns about obstacles to proper training, the performance of necessary, and general poor response to the pandemic, especially in non-1st world countries, it is more probable than not that the 2020 Tokyo games will be pushed back to 2022 or even 2024, but it is unlikely they will be completely cancelled.  Considering recent difficulties in identifying adequate host cities and the the announcement of two host cities ahead of schedule for 2024 and 2028, it would seem likely that the Tokyo Olympics are moved 2024.  Not sure if that really would count as a cancellation.

On the one hand, Japan's COVID vaccination rate remains low and infections are rising, making it unlikely that the event will be safe enough to host. Because of this, Japanese officials appear to have expressed that they might cancel the event, only to backtrack, signaling hesitancy on their part. There is also mass public disapproval of hosting the event, according to survey data. On the other hand, cancelling the event would be an expensive choice, and with an event already creating massive losses for Japan, I am not sure if they would want to do this. Moreover, the changes to the event, such as barring foreign fans, could conceivably be used as justification for arguing that it is still safe to continue. If need be, they could modify the event even more, maybe even barring fans altogether (3/4ths of the Olympic revenue comes from TV, so that seems financially plausible for them to consider). Though it seems likely that they would cancel both the Olympic and Paralympic Games together, considering their interconnected nature, the Paralympic Games also occur later and draw much less fans, making it conceivable that they could carry those on safely while cancelling the Olympics. There is not enough information I could find to confirm this, however, so I kept the probabilities close.
Its just to late, for to many investment.

I believe that the Olympic games of Tokyo will be canceled or at least postponed before May 1st. This prediction is because infection numbers in Japan have begun to climb again and it could be his fourth wave of coronavirus. Indeed, 48% of the infections cases in Tokio are from the UK variant of the virus which is more infectious than the original variant which could generate a quick wave and could generate more deads.
Another argument for this prediction is the nonconformity of the population with the government's handling of the vaccine and making the games will increase that nonconformity because could mean a big risk for the Japanese population and a bad decision coming from the government.

A pesar de las condiciones actuales, no creo que anuncien antes del 1 de mayo la cancelación de los juegos olímpicos ni los paralímpicos. La principal razón detrás de mi razonamiento es que no asistirá público, esto es importante porque ya se están realizando eventos deportivos en que solamente participan los atletas y se llevan a cabo las medidas de precaución necesarias para evitar contagios dentro de los eventos. Tampoco creo que solamente cancelen uno de los dos eventos, esto es porque son de la misma índole, entonces si cancelan uno por razones sanitarias, deberían cancelar el otro de la misma manera. Cabe mencionar que, todavía existen posibilidades de que anuncien la cancelación, esto es porque existe oposición a que se lleven a cabo los juegos, además de que en las ultimas semanas los casos de COVID-19 han aumentado en Japón.
Referencia: https://www.cbssports.com/olympics/news/tokyo-olympics-could-still-be-canceled-due-to-covid-19-pandemic-japanese-officials-say/

@Raven  Japan's Government is concerned about the current spike in COVID-19 cases and has declared emergencies in several Prefectures.  As contagious as the emerging variants are, Japan will cancel the Olympics.

Hay varias razones , en primer lugar tomo en cuenta el costo de este evento , para hacer este evento se aproximo un costo de 15 mil millones de dólares , es un costo muy alto y parar el evento a este momento se presentarían perdidas irrecuperables, además de una clara voluntad del gobierno japonés a desarrollar este evento. Como ya se había anunciado se van a tomar medidas estrictas para los participantes además de limitar al publico no dejando que turistas participen en el evento, por otro lado Japón tiene buenas estadísticas  a nivel mundial en base a como han enfrentado la pandemia pero si tomamos a nivel local, es decir, en Asia Japón comparado con sus vecinos no a tenido tan buenos resultados , de igual manera solo si empeorara la situación de forma drástica  se consideraría a mi parecer una cancelación  de carácter parcial (cancelar Paralímpicos) o si en verdad la situación empeorara sin retorno se consideraría cancelar el evento completo.

En mi opinión, es muy difícil que se cancelen los juegos. Ya se están tomando varias medidas para realizar el evento en situación de pandemia. Una de ellas es la prohibición del público extranjero en los juegos, decisión que fue tomada el 20 de marzo de este año. Además, el 2 de marzo de este año se publicaron una serie de medidas que deberán tomar los atletas y toda persona involucrada en los juegos para la mejor realización de estos en tiempos de pandemia, entre ellas están una cuarentena de 14 días en Japón antes de competir, restricciones a las actividades sociales fuera de la Villa donde alojarán los atletas, medidas para sus desplazamientos entre instalaciones de los Juegos y un sistema de controles regulares de COVID-19 durante los Juegos. Consideradas todas estas medidas que se han tomado, y sabiendo que se ha logrado la realización de otras fiestas deportivas, como lo son el Super Bowl , NBA, etc, creo que es muy posible y probable que se realicen estos juegos olímpicos 2021. Igualmente, dejo un 11% de probabilidades de que los juegos no se realicen. Esto es porque, como ya sabemos, las predicciones son muy difíciles de hacer con temas de pandemia y coronavirus. Un país o ciudad que está bien un día puede empeorar en menos de una semana a una situación incontenible. es por esto que dejo una pequeña posibilidad para que se cancelen los juegos este año.

Por ejemplo, eventos como el tenis o el fútbol, siendo que el último es un deporte de contacto cercano. Además como afirma el presidente del COI "La humanidad se encuentra en un oscuro túnel. Los Juegos Olímpicos de Tokio 2020 pueden ser la luz al final de ese túnel." Esta afirmación nos demuestra la disposición de los organizadores a continuar con este gran evento deportivo. Las Olimpiadas pueden ser realizadas con facilidad si se tienen en cuenta medidas sanitarias, cuarentenas a los atletas previo al evento y que no haya público. Es más, en Japón harán todo lo posible por realizarlo ya que tal como afirma ABE Shinzo el primer ministro japonés, "Estamos para cumplir con nuestra responsabilidad de tener unos Juegos exitosos".

Most likley, no. The deadline for the announcement is 15 days away and up until now only Noth Korea has pulled out. While it is most likey the game will not ocurr (the logistics and risks are simply staggering) the notion that in just 15 days they will be cancelled is difficult to assimilate. The amount of resources, planning, and variables involved require months of foresight for such a decision. Athletes are still preparing, vaccine rollout is still unsteady, and there has been little international coordination until now to prevent the impact of the pandemic with regards to interventions in events. The politics involved also make this difficult. Many top countries with good vaccine roll out or attempting to presume a good status will desire the Olympics to go forth as a way of proving their success, while others won't. Given the importance of records and the participation of countries, the tug of war to ensue will last longer than the deadline allows for an official cancellation of the games.

Despite the low vaccination rate in Japan and overall Japanese population's sentiment against the Games to be held, it is unlikely that Japan will call the Games off for the following reasons: 1. Japan has never went into a complete lockdown, and has therefore shown a medium risk aversion towards the pandemic
2. It is using the rhetoric of "the recovery Olympics", in par with the Antwerp 1920 (post WW1), and Beijing 2008 (post financial crisis)
3. Its biggest regional rivals, China, are set to host the Winter Olympics 2022 - and so Japan would be reluctant to lose the "sign of revival" limelight to Beijing - a sentiment which would be endorsed by IOC major stakeholders s.a. USA, Canada, and major European countries like Germany. Despite the great historic tensions between the two Asian giants, Japan has lately taken a more diplomatic approach with China and the Olympics will be a great platform for Japan to show its equality/superiority indirectly.
4. Japan has put in a lot of financial investment, and postponing the Games from 2020 has already cost it ~ $2-$3bln. I also share the view that in the eventuality that a cancellation is decided, it would hold for both Games. What will tip the scales toward cancellation is when the cost outweighs the benefit. Here the cost would be bad publicity/press caused by an outbreak and possibly folks dying. The benefit is money. TV revenues for the Games have hovered around the $1-3 billion mark in recent years. That's a pretty strong incentive to hold the Games that will be hard to overcome. It also very expensive to host a Games. This one alone is estimated to have cost around $25 billion. Again, another strong incentive. A third strong incentive is that organizers also pretty clearly have what they think is a strong medical/mitgation. That plan will provide a sense of security and enable organizers to convince themselves that holding the Games is the right course, even if they ultimately end up being wrong. When doing their risk analysis the worst case scenario will be an outbreak, which, if one occurs, they can cancel mid games, which is clearly a better option than not having them at all. Another factor organizers will likely consider is that the most fit athletes in the world are not in the target population for folks who are at risk to die from COVID, so they are likely more willing to take some risks, especially with several billion dollars in the balance. Vaccinations are also increasing in number.

Since the opening of the first modern Olympic Games in 1896, the international sports competition has only been canceled three times: once during World War I (1916) and twice during World War II (1940, 1944) (https://www.history.com/news/olympics-postponed-cancelled). An outright cancellation has thus clearly required extraordinary circumstances in the past. However, the Covid-19 pandemic is an extraordinary circumstance. A key difference between the world wars of the past century and the current pandemic, though, is that relief, if not an outright end, is in sight. Multiple effective vaccines are in production and distribution worldwide, with updates that protect from known immune-escape variants on the way. While this coming fall and winter (2020-2021) could be dominated by circulation of immune-escape variants, it seems likely to me that the combined effects of cumulative exposure and vaccination will bring worldwide immunity to far higher levels and virus circulation to far lower levels by next summer in the Northern Hemisphere. Thus, it would seem most likely to me that the most probable worst-case scenario would be postponement of the Olympics and/or Paralympics to next summer.  With the games scheduled to take place only four months away (as of today, 3/22/21), the window for the games to be postponed or canceled is narrowing. Business commitments will be increasingly difficult to cancel as we move closer to the events. Meanwhile, the Tokyo Olympic organizing committee has consistently publicly expressed its commitment to holding the Olympic games, and two days ago, the committee issued a statement saying that international spectators would not be allowed at the Olympic games. The Tokyo Olympic organizing committee is also trying to balance the goals of making the Olympics happen and bringing a tourism boost to the Japanese economy (http://www.asahi.com/ajw/articles/14288811). Moreover, public sentiment in Japan and at least several other nations is also clearly against holding the Olympic games this summer (http://www.asahi.com/ajw/articles/14291400). The Tokyo Olympics organizing committee is clearly doing everything in its power to make the Olympic games happen, but it's certainly possible that they will end up bowing to public and potential political pressure not to hold the games this summer. But I can't imagine they will give up on holding the Olympics altogether. That would be a tremendous loss economically and in terms of losing face. I would suspect that the Olympics and Paralympics games will be postponed or canceled in tandem. I see no reason why one would take place without the other. There are large economic efficiencies to holding both together, as well. So the question in my mind is not whether they will be canceled this year but whether they will be postponed until next summer. I'd give that possibility approximately a 50/50 chance. I'll give low probabilities to each possibility, however, because nothing in life is certain.

Base rate of 6% of Olympic games cancelled over the last 100 years (due to WWI and WWII). On the one hand, this rate should fall due to factors such as the advanced stage of planning, Japan's great desire to save face and their not relying on revenue generated from travellers, making it possible to let the games go ahead without foreign spectators (as currently planned).  However, there are some scenarios in which the games would nevertheless get postponed again, such as an outbreak of a vaccine-resistant strain either in Japan or in many countries around the world stopping athletes from participating. Another alternative is that Japan levies heavy travels restrictions on afflicted countries, which causes a substantial proportion of athletes to be unable to participate and thus warrant another postponement. However, I find these unlikely as it is common to have travel exemptions for athletes and some countries (like Russia, the UK and the US) are likely to have their athletes vaccinated by then. Further, a postponement does not unconditionally entail a cancellation. Hence, I think the base rate should fall to around 4%, whereby I agree with others that it is most likely that both games get cancelled rather than just one.

Overall, low cancellation chance due to the question timeframe, commitment by the PM to the games under pressure, low public support for a full cancellation, a strong IOC interest in the games happening in some form, the nationalist narrative against China, the treatment of the games by Japanese sponsors as a national project to be supported, the amount staked by the PM on the games happening, and consistent strong support by the IOC and Japanese government with the current state of affairs being very foreseeable. Cancellation risk may come from disagreements among the athletes/IOC/Japanese government about postponement vs. cancellation, and/or a push for delay or postponement by sponsors if the torch relay confirms worries about the games being bad content, and/or an erosion in public support amidst a COVID surge.  A critical piece to consider is that the games start on July 23, and the question is asking about cancellation before May 1. It’s not “will the games be cancelled” period, its will they be preemptively cancelled in the coming weeks. Will they be cancelled at all I would put closer to maybe 8%. I think the first key questions to answer are what public sentiment in Japan will be like around the games in the coming weeks, if/how the government will respond, and if/how the IOC will respond. Japanese citizens have been largely opposed to the games happening on schedule. The most recent poll I’ve seen was at 61% calling for postponing or cancelling, though that’s down from 80%+ back in January when COVID was worse. Japan has had issues with vaccines in the past and public confidence has been shaky and the rollout slow, so the population will not be as thoroughly vaccinated as other wealthy countries in the run-up to the games. Further, Japan will most likely see an increase in cases over the next few weeks mirroring the rest of the world, as their current cases have plateaued.  That increase will likely lead to decreased support for the games going ahead as planned, raising the chance of cancellation. However, Tokyo has already put in new lockdown measures, and the country does have a good track record for containing the virus. I wouldn’t expect opposition (or caseloads) to return to January levels either considering the seasonality. It is possible for opposition to go up more quickly though, since we’re getting closer to the scheduled start of the games and the idea of the games starting and tourists or Japanese people coming to spectate will feel more real. The games will be happening in the summer though, so the Japanese government/IOC may be more willing to bet on cases being lower and support higher by the time the games come. How would the IOC and Japanese government respond to increased or consistent opposition? The IOC has been adamant about hosting the games and has a huge interest in the games continuing even if without fans. 73% of their historic revenue is from TV rights (maybe less so if the games are less hyped this year though), so a cancellation is far worse than even a worst-case no-fans Olympics. The IOC will almost certainly want to go ahead, so the most likely source of a response would be from the Japanese government.  PM Suga would most likely not want to cancel the games early. Regarding COVID, he did have a program promoting domestic travel which was cancelled, and his popularity took a hit as it was blamed for Japan’s recent spike in COVID cases, so he may be more conservative around COVID in the future. However, as an advisor to Abe he was very focused on economic development and seems to have kept that focus as PM, despite recent backtracking on the GoTo program, and spectators at the Olympics are usually expected to be a huge economic boon. He has also been publicly in support of the games and pledged to continue preparations in his New Year’s address, and that was when public opposition was even higher, so a preemptive cancelling of a promise made in those conditions would be a pretty big move. This type of scenario would've been very foreseeable as well in January when he reaffirmed that the games will go ahead, nobody was expecting COVID to be cured by June. The current state of affairs is probably what would be expected, something very significant and unexpected would probably be needed to result in a cancellation. Another consideration is the timing of the 2022 Beijing Winter Olympics in February, 7 months after the start of the Tokyo Olympics. Suga has pitched the games as a symbol of humanity overcoming the coronavirus, a theme in which China has been seeking to pitch itself as a global leader. Suga doesn’t seem to be the nationalist that Abe was, but nationalism remains a theme in the LDP, not to mention the importance of Japan’s alliance with the US. To cancel the games, only to have China host the first post-COVID Olympics a few months later, would be a very bad look. On the other hand, having to cancel the games amid an outbreak may look even worse. Thus far the attitudes of Japan and the IOC have been to have contingency plans regarding spectators depending on how serious a threat COVID is, and to push countries to prioritize vaccinations for athletes (while tiptoeing around the ethics of doing so).  The Japanese public doesn’t support cancelling outright either. In the most recent poll only 28% of Japanese respondents said they wanted the games to be cancelled. Postponing has been the more popular option. An outright cancellation would be a pretty huge loss for pretty much every party involved as well, especially compared to postponing. The IOC’s precious broadcast rights can at least be partially saved by postponing rather than cancelling. The Japanese government would be embarrassed and sad to see the economic activity never happen at all instead of just happen later. Most of the discussions (that are being reported) currently happening are around how to accommodate spectators, with no spectators at all as a worst case, so a jump to cancellation would probably be pretty sudden internally as well.  Where could a cancellation come from? Cancellation may come from disagreement among the parties involved. The IOC and Japan could disagree over timing (or something else) and Japan could force a cancellation rather than compromise, and scapegoat the IOC in the process. It may become clear that the preparations for the games for getting athletes there or keeping them safe are just woefully inadequate, though before May would probably be a bit early to say. The athletes could force a cancellation by refusing to accept a postponement.  Japanese sponsors may pull out over the risk of being associated with an unpopular games. Back in January Reuters ran an article about sponsors rolling back or delaying advertising as Japanese cases hit a peak, public confidence dipped, and concerns about a delay weren’t exactly addressed. The torch relay is coming up in late March, and it’s unclear whether spectators will be allowed amidst Tokyo’s lockdown. Torch runners running down empty streets may be the depressing sight necessary to push sponsors to force a change. The games seem to have been treated as a national project by the sponsors though, which makes a full pullout unlikely and would allow for some flexibility with the costs of another postponement, but they may also reach the conclusion that a depressing games is worse than no games.  As for recent news, Japan has decided not to allow overseas spectators, which should definitely help quell the concerns of Japanese citizens about virus spread. Suga had a call with Bill Gates emphasizing the importance of vaccinations for the games, meaning its more likely that athletes will have some access to vaccines. I'll need to reassess during and after the torch relay and see how things look.

Fans will reportedly not be allowed to travel to Japan for the Tokyo Olympics or Paralympics this summer, according to multiple reports. The country made the decision to ban foreign visitors from the Tokyo Olympics due to the threat of the coronavirus pandemic. The report came on Tuesday from the Kyodo news agency, citing Japanese government officials. The news has not yet been confirmed by the Japanese government or Olympic officials. While the news may be disappointing to those wanting to make the trip, the country is being on the safe side. At one point, fans were unsure if there would even be a Summer Olympics, after the games were delayed from 2020 to 2021 and amidst growing worry regarding the pandemic. They still plan to have the Olympics in summer of 2021 despite the pushback from many fans, media members and Japanese citizens. Japan has a population of over 126 million, and has reported just over 8,000 deaths from COVID-19, according to CBS News. Even without allowing visitors from abroad, there is still concern about the spread of the virus, given how many athletes and personnel will be making the trip.

Although the Olympic Games might be cancelled, it is unlikely they would be cancelled before May 1st.  Until 2020 the Olympics had only been cancelled because of war so we can only compare to the 2020 cancellation.  In 2020, the decision to cancel increased as more information was made available.  In 2021 there is more knowledge about Covid but there are new factors with evolving information (namely regarding vaccines and variants).  The IOC and Japan are likely to take the same wait and see approach that they took in 2020 because there is so much at stake (athletes careers, national Olympic committee funding, Japanese suck costs...).  The Japanese government, businesses and people are not in favor of going forward with the Olympics.  However, the IOC and national Olympic committees are in favor and the president has said that the games will go on and there is no plan B.  There are three factors that are being looked at: vaccination trends (this is increasing worldwide but the Japanese rollout is slow and the population hesitant), variant trends (these were increasing but there is more certainty that the vaccines will have some effect in suppressing their spread), and travel (governments are taking a cautious approach, especially as different countries have different vaccination rates). The betting market slightly favors that cancellation will occur (by August, not necessarily May 1) but the trend has been decreasing as optimism grows with the vaccines and fewer cases. The three factors (vaccines, variant, travel) still have uncertainty since vaccine rollout is relatively new and countries are being cautious with travel restrictions.  A wait and see approach is necessary since the data is too green with regard to these factors.  As such the IOC and Japan are likely to wait as long as possible before reaching a verdict.  May 1 is too close and a decision to cancel is therefore unlikely by then.  If a decision is made it is more likely to be another postponement than an altogether cancellation since there is so much invested already.  That Paralympics are scheduled for one month later so a verdict regarding that event is even less likely though it is probable that a decision for both events will be made at once since they rely on each other for synergies.

The likelihood that the 2020 Summer Olympics and/or Paralympics will be cancelled or postponed again is very slim.  The International Olympic Committee president Jason Bach is on record a number of times saying something to the effect that the games will not be cancelled, despite rumors and stories around the world that they might. “We have, at this moment, no reason whatsoever to believe that the Olympic Games in Tokyo will not open on 23 July in the Olympic stadium in Tokyo,” Bach told Japan’s Kyodo News. “This is why there is no plan B and this is why we are fully committed to make these Games safe and successful.” (Bruton 2021).  The official Tokyo 2020 games website (https://tokyo2020.org/en/)  is updated regularly with headlines, and information about both the Olympic Games and the Paralympic Games. There is a countdown clock at the top of the webpage, and no indications that the games will be cancelled again.  I have given an 8% prediction that both games will be cancelled, due to the information that “77% of Japanese people polled by NHK said they want the Tokyo Games to be either canceled or further postponed” (Bruton 2021).  But I do not believe that they would cancel only 1 of the games and not the other, so both of those sections were given a 0% prediction.  Countless news articles and reports noting that there are no official intentions to cancel the games again led me to a 92% prediction that there will be no cancellation by May 1, 2021.  Bruton, M. (2021). There are huge disagreements between different forecasting platforms about whether the Olympics will happen or not. Surely, the questions are different in the ways meaningfully affecting their resolutions; but I still can't comprehend the contradictions. Here are the questions (along with the important bits of clarifications):
* Good Judgement Open: Before 1 May 2021, will it be officially announced that the Tokyo 2020 Summer Olympics and/or Paralympics will be canceled? Postponement(s) alone would not count.
* Polymarket: Will the Tokyo Summer Olympics be cancelled or postponed by May 1, 2021?
* Good Judgement Superforecasters: What will happen next with regard to the Tokyo Olympics? (The Games will begin vs. the Games will be postponed again by more than a day vs. the Games will be cancelled.)
* Metaculus: Will the Tokyo 2020 Olympic Games take place in 2021? The question resolves negative if the Olympics does not take place in 2021. An Olympics spread out over multiple countries will still count. Here are the probabilities for the "Olympic Games happening" side (subject to questions operationalizations) at the time of writing (2021-03-02 17:50 UTC+3):
* GJO: 82%
* Poly: 78%
* Supers: 97%
* Metaculus: 60% Here are the comparisons between predictions:
* GJO and Poly are consistent with each other as the questions disagree on whether postponement is allowed.
* Poly and Supers are inconsistent as I doubt that anyone assigns a non-negligible probability to "Olympics will be officially cancelled/postponed by May 1 but will happen on schedule anyway."
* The difference between Superforecasters and Metaculus is the most striking as a positive resolution of Supers' question will trigger positive resolution on Metaculus. Here are the links:
* https://www.gjopen.com/questions/1668
* https://goodjudgment.io/superforecasts
* https://polymarket.com/market/will-the-tokyo-summer-olympics-be-cancelled-or-postponed
* https://www.metaculus.com/questions/5555

SEMANTICS: 
If the games are postponed, the answer is "no".
If the games are canceled after 1 May 2021, the answer is "no".
Reducing the size of the Olympics and not allowing spectators still result in “no” being the right answer.  OUTSIDE VIEW:
So far 28 summer and 23 winter Olympics have been held, 3 summer and 2 winter Olympics have been canceled. This gives a base rate of p=5/56=9% cancellations. 
However, all these cancelations have been due to two events only (WWI and WWII).  INSIDE VIEW: For “yes”:
While COVID cases have fallen worldwide since the peak in mid-January and vaccination efforts are underway, a large number of people are infected and new strains of the virus slow progress.
P = 9% + 51% = 60% More than 80% of Japanese people surveyed in January polls said that the Olympics should be called off or won’t happen. (https://apnews.com/article/tokyo-olympics-coronavirus-dad73f073a9f60f7578b6434092b748f)
P = 60%+10%= 70% For “no”:
It is known that some professional sports have continued operating for months without having to shut down by testing effectively and forming bubbles. 
P = 70% - 40% = 30% In early February a playbook was published with concrete plans as to how to deal with COVID. Vaccines are not required. (https://tokyo2020.org/en/news/first-playbook-published-outlining-measures-to-deliver-safe-and-successful-games).
P = 30% - 20% = 10% Almost 75% of IOC income is from broadcast revenues, so holding the Olympics without spectators, would not be a large economic problem, and the Olympics is an international symbol of beating COVID.
P = 10%- 5% = 5% Prime Minister Shinzo Abe ordered the postponement of the Olympics in 2020 while being criticized for his lenient treatment of COVID. 
New Prime Minister by Yoshihide Suga seems to have a similar take on COVID. 
P = 5%- 2% = 3% Because the Paralympics happen a month after the Olympics, they slightly less likely to be canceled by 1 May 2021.

There are too many financial interests at play and Tokyo has a big stake. In a recent BBC episode of business daily, experts reckoned it was more likely to see a scaled-down version of the Olympics as Tokyo would be liable to heavy penalties to broadcasting rightholders should they cancel again without a strong rationale. Force majeure cannot be invoked when other major sporting events are going ahead despite the lack of public. On top of that, I would take the total of Olympics held in the past 100 years and how many have been cancelled to create a baseline. Only the 1940 and 1944 Olympics have been cancelled since 1920 and the Tokyo 2020 has been postponed (but I'll take that as another cancelation for the purposes of this answer). That means 23/25 games went ahead (92% of the time). The fact that the most recent delay was last year could only cloud my judgment through proximity bias (is that a thing?). I'll go down to 85% to compensate for the fact the pandemic is still going strong and I must follow how different strains will play this out.

As @p00h below has noted below, the base rate is approx 10%/7%, but time is now very short (I have only just joined the site), so can be cut to more like 1%. 
COVID is the main risk of cancellation and may still be significant, directly or indirectly.  I'd start by taking the risk of cancellation up to 25% after a skim of info.
- Case rates in Japan have fallen substantially since the Jan21 peak, but vaccination looks to be rolling out slowly. This lowers the chance of cancelling by, say, 10%.
- Worldwide rates will continue for the period to be very variable - some athletes will come from high incidence locations.
- Keeping people safe is an important political goal and is something of a mitigator of the power of the undoubted political and financial "sunk investment" in encouraging holding the games no matter what.
- given this, and the report that the Japanese people may be negative about the Olympics (press: 80% against, Jan 21), the politics is less clear than I initially imagined. Taking these 2 last factors, I add 5% back.
On the side of saying 'no', as others have noted, mitigations to Covid are now well developed - testing and quarantining, masking and distancing, restrictions on crowds, etc.
- the G7 have reportedly stated their support for the games continuing, as have IOC officials.
- Other sporting events (tennis, football) have also now restarted or continued, including internationally, suggesting it's unlikely nations or sporting bodies will want to withdraw. Take off 10%.
However, it is not surprising that no one is talking up the chance of cancellation - all those speaking have an inherent interest in being optimistic. That does not mean that the Japanese government won't be forced to make the ultimate difficult call eventually. Add back 5 for the gap.
It is worth noting that it is possible, if unlikely, that other causes of cancellation could arise
- a major earthquake in the Tokyo area;
- significant volcanic activity & ash clouds causing air travel to be severely disrupted
For both these, the chance is deemed extremely low due to short time span in mind, but not completely negligible. I add 1% to the "both" category for these and any other 'black swans'.
I can see the potential for paralympians to be slightly more at risk, so add 1% to the minimal risk of just one being cancelled, not the other. But overall, I see little political or practical point otherwise in separating the two. One gap in my knowledge is whether the decision-makers will  ultimately be the same or different (e.g. would different decision-makers weigh their duty of care differently for their paralympians?).

The NYT story (link below), about the significant logistical problems and frustrations encountered in trying to hold the Australian Open tennis tournament, leads me to hold steady in my view that both games will be cancelled.[1]  The amount of quarantine space alone required for many multiples of athletes, coaches, and trainers from all over the globe compared with a much smaller tennis tournament highlight the challenge Olympic organizers will face.   Six months before the Games are to commence, half of Japan's population is under emergency lockdown, hospitals are overwhelmed with COVID patients, and the so-called "indispensable" chief of the Tokyo Organizing Committee has just resigned in disgrace yesterday.[2]  Vaccinations have yet to start in Japan and are not due to begin until March.  The public remains strongly opposed to holding the games.[3] With the new global consciousness about equity, especially among elite cosmopolitan global institutions like the IOC, it seems to me that they would be disinclined to hold the Olympics and not the Paralympics, as some have been forecasting here. Against my view, public opinion is much more volatile than I imagined.  The latest poll of those Japanese opposed to the Games going forward is 60%, down from 80% in January.[3]  Still, only 38% of public favor holding the games.  Also against my view, the Olympics exist primarily as a programming content vehicle for advertisements by powerful multinational corporations.   The suasion those companies hold with the IOC and Japanese officials should not be underestimated. The emergence of the three mutant strains of COVID, one of which has a 70% higher transmission rate than the kind predominant in the U.S,  have dampened my previous view that the games would go forward.[1]  Vaccines are less effective against these strains that are likely to predominate by March around the world, allowing exponential spread compared to original strains.  Our ability to manufacture boosters will  be constrained for many months, pushing our ability to achieve 85% herd immunity well into 2022.  Even if we can vaccinate developed countries,it is hard to imagine providing a level of protection to allow athletes and visitors from the developing world.[2]   To hold a successful, safe games, we would need widespread global distribution of vaccines and declining infection rates.  Vaccine nationalism and the explosion of infections where the variants predominate undercut a science-based approach.  Even if it is logistically possible, Japanese public opinion is overwhelmingly opposed.[3]  For something seen by most people as a "nice to have" event, it is hard to see how the Japanese government will allow a massive global super spreader event when 80 percent of the public opposes it, up almost 20 points from a month ago.  The US Government has already told citizens they need to have a plan B if they choose to travel during the pandemic because Uncle Sam most likely will not be able to help them get home.[4]  I imagine other countries will say something similar. One imagines that the insurance firms will be putting the arm on Japan, the IOC, and the wannabe contestants to make the Games happen.   Do remember, though, that "losses" is the insurance industry's word for "claims paid," which is what they are in business to do, and the purpose for which they collect premiums.  This bit of wordplay has fooled many non-specialist legislators and reporters over the years.  Huge "losses" doesn't mean they aren't making huge profits, only that they are performing their function in society.  Save your tears for those policyholders who got cancelled when they were two days late with a premium payment last year, or who discovered that their plight was exempted in the small print.

There is too much money at stake for the games to be outright cancelled, especially as the vaccine rollout is beginning worldwide. The sunk costs in building the venues and Olympic village are enormous and trying to recoup anything with television revenues and advertising is a must at this point. 
Cancelling the games in totality would be an unprecedented move; limiting competition based on vaccination, however, may be a more appropriate path if the IOC feels that some more strict measures are needed. If a cancellation were to occur, it would have taken place in 2020. The overall emotional attachment as well of a worldwide 'celebration' of sorts for enduring and overcoming the pandemic is also a pressing factor to get the games to go on.
Overall, it is most likely an all or neither; cancelling simply one event (which would most likely be the paralympics) would be a terrible optic that would set back progress by years and something that would draw much global outrage and condemnation, especially from western nations.
Japan is likely to declare a second state of emergency Jan 7th. While not a severe as those imposed in UK/Europe, this does suggest a higher chance of cancellation.

2 bits of info to add today. 1. One of the economists podcasts interviewed Edwin Moses recently (episode released this morning my time), the former track and field athlete says there is next to no chance of the Olympics going ahead before 2022 without restrictions - noting he does not say cancellation, and was considering the numbers for a normal Olympics. He continues and states he would back a cancellation if it came to that. 2. It has been 15 days since Perth hosted the return of sports and the crowd numbers are; 22k on 16th, 25k on 19th, 25k on 26th and 20k on 27th. We currently stand at 6 active cases and an increase of 8 cases since 14/07 (noting we effectively reopened society on 14th June, but not borders - the state is closed to the rest of Australia, and still has internal borders closed).  Why I think this is important (apart from local bias), is I believe we are operating a model that could be expanded upon as a minimum standard that would allow the Games to happen. We have a low case count and have only let through competing athletes and support staff, they were required to undergo 2 weeks quarantine and testing before being allowed into the community, there is still no non-essential travel, there has been a reasonable community response and with very few exceptions people have cooperated with government orders.  All things I believe Japan are capable of doing and delivering.

Even if an effective immunization is developed and approved by, say, 31 Dec 2020, there is no method for a global inoculation campaign to take effect for a global gathering to occur in Summer 2021-anywhere.  Possible alternate olympic outcome is to shift Summer Olympics back to 'same year as Winter Games' for 2022 only.

After reading on multiple sources, came to the conclusion that the dominant drivers of decision are: existence of a vaccine, if so ability to scale and made available in a sufficiently large number of countries (100+), chances of the event happening with closed doors (happening nevertheless). Built a decision tree with subjective conditional probabilities. Result is that the uncertainty around the existence of the vaccine dominates. Estimated the chances to be between 10% and 60% to have a vaccine (here the large uncertainty at this point in time). The baysian computation yields a 50-50% chances of happening, rounded. Not giving much credit to only one of the events happening mostly for reputation risk. Thanks for the links in the most upvoted section.

The organizing committee does not want to cancel the Olympics and will delay any announcement as long as possible. In March 2020, there was already many calls to postpone or cancel the games from many people and the Japanese organizing committee "dragged their feet" in making an announcement. It wasn't until athletes and national sports governing bodies made decisions to boycott the Olympics that they finally postponed the games until 2021 (3).  With a July 23, 2021 start date (4) and wanting to end the Olympics no later than the end of summer 2021 (5), this gives the Tokyo organizing committee only 2.5 months to finalize all organization plans. Significant additional costs are already incurred due to rescheduling (4) that a plan will need to be in place prior to May 1, 2021. Barring a miraculous containment of the virus, to risk the health of athletes, the games will not go ahead and likely be cancelled by May 1, 2021 (see the recent Djokovic friendly tournament for how things can go for athletes in close contact). Lastly, they will not cancel one games and let the other proceed. (1) https://olympic.ca/press/team-canada-will-not-send-athletes-to-games-in-summer-2020-due-to-covid-19-risks/

Overall I judge it as likely that neither event will be cancelled. In the event of a vaccine identified and rolled out by the time of the event (admittedly not likely) then the events will in all likelihood go ahead. If not, there is still the potential for the event to go ahead on the basis that cases globally may have significantly reduced, though admittedly this would take a significant risk. In common with other sports events I judge that there will be strong economic incentives to try and do the event behind closed doors if not possible to do it with an attending audience - this eventuality may ultimately be the most likely since they will also have time to prepare for this arrangement. If this is not possible, the IOC/Japan can still choose to postpone again rather than cancel - though noises out of the IOC suggests that this is not a desirable outcome. In principle there is a higher likelihood that the paralympics would be cancelled than the olympics because of the greater risk to the athletes (indeed, I cannot foresee a reason why the olympics would be cancelled on its own) but the public messages on this topic suggest that they are being considered together.

Even if there are no fans allowed (which makes it so that Japan will likely suffer a large $ loss), there will still be 11,000 athletes and thousands of support staff from more than 200 teams coming together in Tokyo [1]. Given the difficulty of starting sports on a much smaller scale [2, 3], I don't see how this much larger arrangement can be done without a safe and effective vaccine. The Metaculus community's median prediction for when a vaccine that has demonstrated an efficacy rate >75% will be administered to 10,000 people is August 2021 [4] — which is after the start of the 2021 Tokyo Summer Olympics (and in any case athletes will presumably not be the first to get a vaccine — healthcare workers and the elderly will be prioritized).
